thread.title: Baseball Saturday -- Top-5 Toronto Blue Jays moments from regular season
thread.title_full: Baseball Saturday -- Top-5 Toronto Blue Jays moments from regular season

title: Baseball Saturday -- Top-5 Toronto Blue Jays moments from regular season
text:
Report an error 
Even before the first playoff pitch is thrown out, this has been a season to remember for the Toronto Blue Jays. 
The Jays 2015 slate — which wraps up with game No. 162 on Sunday in Tampa — has been chock-full of great moments. 
There was Josh Donaldson’s Superman leap into the stands to nab a foul pop-up during a game against the Tampa Bay Rays back in June. There was Josh Donaldson’s Superman slide to score from third on a pop-up to very shallow centre in a game a month ago against the Cleveland Indians. There was Josh Donaldson’s Superman timing, emerging from a phone booth in the bottom of the ninth at Rogers Centre to save the day with a walk-off home run in the Jays final regular-season home game. 
OK, so we could put together an all-Donaldson top-five list if we wanted, but in the spirit of this team game of ours, the final edition of Baseball Saturday for the season presents its top-five Jays moments from this past regular season. 

1. JUNE 12 -- Comeback for the ages 
It certainly appeared as though the Jays eight-game win streak was about to end. With Drew Hutchison on the mound at Fenway Park in Boston, the Jays found themselves down 5-0 to the Red Sox after just an inning and then behind 8-1 when Hutchison was finally pulled in the third. The Jays got three runs in the fifth to pull to within four. So you’re tellin’ me there’s a chance?! Indeed, the Jays kicked the door open in the seventh inning when the first six batters all hit safely en route to a nine-run inning and, ultimately, a 13-10 win. 
2. JULY 30 -- The Price was right 
“Am I dreaming? @DAVIDprice14 can’t wait to get you here. Welcome my friend.. It’s getting real in the #6ix #Bluejays #WeOwnTheNorth #Tdot.” Newly-acquired Jays reliever LaTroy Hawkins (@LaTroyHawkins32) tweeted those words at 10:22 a.m. the morning of July 30 in response to the latest blockbuster from GM Alex Anthopoulos that plucked David Price from the Detroit Tigers. After the World Series is over — and once we find out whether or not Price re-signs with the Jays — we can debate which was the bigger get: Price or Donaldson. 
3. AUG. 29 -- Hats off to Edwin 
If you’re a fan of ‘moments,’ and you were watching the Jays 15-1 win over the Tigers on Aug. 29 at Rogers Centre, you were smiling. Edwin Encarnacion’s grand-slam in the seventh inning made history — he joined Roy Howell as the only two Jays players to drive in nine runs in a single game — but what happened afterward was equally memorable and quintessentially Canadian. With Edwin in the dugout, hats rained down onto the field celebrating his third home run of the game. When Encarnacion was informed what a ‘hat-trick’ was, he couldn’t help but smile along with the rest of us. 
4. SEPT. 23 -- Russell Martin's home run 
It may not be the biggest home run he’s ever hit, but when Jays C Russell Martin hangs up his mitt at the end of his career, it will certainly be in the conversation. When the Blue Jays hooked up with the New York Yankees in the third game of a best-of-three series, the fate of the AL East was still in doubt. The teams had split the first two games, and the Jays sat 21/2 games up on the Yankees. A win by the Yanks would have brought them within striking distance with 10 games left. But Martin’s three-run blast in the seventh inning put what had been a close game up to that point, out of reach. 

5. SEPT. 30 -- Jays clinch AL East 
Focus should never be an issue for a big-league ballplayer, but during the second half of Wednesday’s doubleheader against the host Baltimore Orioles, the Jays could be forgiven if they looked like they had other things on their minds. They had already clinched the division with a win in the opener, and there was champagne waiting for them. Once the final out was recorded in the night-cap, the players retired to the locker room and uncorked the bubbly. During a beer-and-champagne-fuelled post-game interview, Donaldson, for one final time, was serenaded with chants of “MVP! MVP!”— this time by his teammates. 
3Up 
1. 1B Lucas Duda, New York Mets 
Partly fuelled by Tuesday’s two-homer game, Duda hit .375 last week blasting five home runs and collecting 13 RBI along the way. 
2. SP Jerad Eickhoff, Philadelphia Phillies 
Phillies young starter has had a nice end to the season, striking out 20 batters in his last 14 innings over the course of two starts. He won them both, of course. 
3. SP Clayton Kershaw, L.A. Dodgers 
Dodgers ace – or one of them, anyway – has been lights-out over the last month: 5-1, 44 IP, 58 SO, 1.84 ERA, 0.82 WHIP. 

3Down 
1. RF Alex Rios, Kansas City Royals 
Royals outfielder has been battling back stiffness for the last little while, and it’s showed. He has just two hits to show for his last 20 at-bats. 
2. SP Scott Kazmir, Houston Astros 
With his Astros fighting to keep hold of one of the AL wildcards, Kazmir had a rough go in two starts: 0-2, 8 IP, 17 H, 12 R, 10 ER, 11.25 ERA. 
3. RP Danny Farquhar, Seattle Mariners 
There were guys who put up worse numbers, but the Mariners reliever made three appearances last week and picked up the loss in all three. 

“The whole country is behind you @BlueJays! Congrats on clinching the AL East! #ComeTogether.” 
Prime Minister Stephen Harper (@pmharper) via Twitter.
